data.title: Twitter has suspended 70,000 QAnon accounts since U.S. Capitol riot
data.text: Twitter has suspended more than 70,000 accounts associated with the far-right QAnon conspiracy theory.

data.title: Trump's Social Media Ban Is 'Censorship,' Says Eurasia Group
data.text: Jan.11 -- Joe Lieber, Eurasia Group managing director for the U.S., says the President Donald Trump social media ban is censorship. He speaks on "Bloomberg Markets.

data.title: The sudden crackdown on social media and fallout from the Trump ban
data.text: Rich Greenfield from LightShed Partners discusses the immediate impact of banning Trump and other right-wing figures on social media platforms. With CNBC's Melissa Lee and the Fast Money traders, Guy Adami, Tim Seymour, Dan Nathan and Karen Finerman.

data.title: Twitter Stock Drops In Reaction To Permanent Suspension Of Trump
data.text: Twitter stock dropped Monday in reaction to its decision to permanently kick President Donald Trump off its social media platform. The ban was announced after the market close on Friday.

data.title: TWTR Stock Price Decreases 6.41%: Why It Happened
data.text: The stock price of Twitter (NYSE: TWTR) decreased by 6.41% as it went from a previous close of $51.48 to $48.18. This is why it happened.

data.title: Big Tech stocks plunge as backlash against Silicon Valley grows
data.text: Big Tech stocks tumbled Monday amid a growing backlash against Silicon Valley's crackdown on President Trump and his supporters. Twitter shares plunged as much as 12 percent to $45.17 in the first trading session after it booted Trump from the platform on Friday, saying his account posed a “risk of further incitement of violence” after his supporters.

data.title: How much money was President Trump's Twitter account worth?
data.text: Shares in the social-media company fell 6% Monday. ‘Most advertisers won't touch anything Trump related,' one analyst said.

data.title: NIO Hits Records on Sedan Reveal; Twitter Pulls Stock Markets Down on Trump Ban
data.text: Stocks pulled back from their all-time highs.

data.title: Why Twitter Stock Was Slumping Today
data.text: Shares of the social media stock pulled back after the company's decision to ban President Trump on Friday evening.

data.title: Twitter's stock falls after Trump's account is suspended
data.text: Shares of Twitter fell Monday after the company announced late Friday that it had permanently banned President Donald Trump from the platform.

data.title: Kara Swisher: Twitter has to find a business model besides enragement
data.text: Recode co-founder Kara Swisher joins "Squawk Alley" to discuss Twitter's ban of President Trump, and the tech backlash against social media platform Parler.

data.title: Trump to launch final stand against Big Tech: Report
data.text: President Trump expected to take a final stand against big tech before leaving the White House. Subscribe to Fox Business!

data.title: ‘Problematic' And ‘Perplexing': European Leaders Side With Trump Over Twitter Ban
data.text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said Big Tech companies should not be the arbiters of free speech, urging U.S. government regulation to clean up tech platforms.

data.title: The Ratings Game: Twitter's Trump ban could hurt user engagement but appeal to advertisers, analyst say
data.text: Twitter Inc. is leading social-media stocks lower Monday as investors digest a new reality for the services after Twitter permanently banned President Donald Trump from its platform and Facebook Inc. said it would restrict him at least until the end of his term.

data.title: Jack Dorsey reportedly banned Trump's Twitter account while he was on vacation in French Polynesia (TW)
data.text: Jack Dorsey was reportedly on vacation in the South Pacific as Twitter debated what to do about President Donald Trump's Twitter account following riots at the Capitol last week.  According to The New York Times' Kate Conger and Mike Isaac, Dorsey was vacationing on an island in French Polynesia, calling into meetings as Twitter worked internally to handle the fallout from the violent insurrection. On Friday evening, the company decided to permanently ban Trump's account "due to the risk of further incitement of violence," the company said in a tweet.

data.title: Germany's Merkel hits out at Twitter over 'problematic' Trump ban
data.text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel blasted Twitter's decision to ban U.S. President Donald Trump.

data.title: Cramer: Twitter may have trouble attracting users without Trump on the platform
data.text: "The surprise factor of going to Twitter — which was, of course, the president — is gone," CNBC's Jim Cramer said Monday. "I do believe Twitter's got to come up with a new thesis very, very quickly….

data.title: Twitter, Social Media Stocks Trading Lower After Trump Ban
data.text: Shares of Twitter fell more than 10% in early trading after the social media platform banned President Donald Trump permanently Friday for risk of inciting violence, but had regained some ground by late morning. The stock is changing hands at $48, down about 6.7%. Trump egged on supporters at a rally Wednesday, reiterating false claims...

data.title: Twitter Is The Worst Company On Planet Earth. Here's How To Bet Against The Stock—and Deactivate Your Account
data.text: Twitter has shown little to no sequential growth in its user base of late (details below) but it is still valued like its Big Tech growth-y brethren.

data.title: Twitter Boots Trump, Stock Falls: What Investors Need To Know
data.text: In the closing days of his term, President Donald Trump has had his Twitter Inc (NYSE: TWTR) account suspended as social media giants Twitter, Facebook, Inc. (NASDAQ: FB), Amazon.com (NASDAQ: AMZN) and others attempt to prevent further deadly protests following last week's events at the U.S. Capitol. What Happened?

data.title: German Chancellor Merkel sees Twitter ban on Trump as 'problematic': report
data.text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel may not be among those not cheering Twitter's decision to permanently ban President Donald Trump. The ability to express oneself freely is a right of "elementary significance," Merkel's spokesman, Steffen Seibert, reportedly said on Monday when asked about the microblogger's Friday decision to ban Trump after some of his supporters violently stormed the U.S. Capitol building, leaving five dead.

data.title: More social media platforms restrict or ban President Trump Twitter and Parler accounts
data.text: #TrumpTwitter #Parlerbanned #YahooFinance Yahoo Finance's Alexis Keenan breaks down why President Trump and Parler were banned or restricted from social media accounts. data.title: Twitter shares sink after Trump's account deleted
data.text: Twitter Inc. shares were under pressure Monday after the social-media platform deleted President Trump's account in a move the company said was done to prevent further violence.

data.title: Greycroft's Alan Patricof: Social media companies have effectively become utilities
data.text: Alan Patricof, co-founder and managing director of venture capital firm Greycroft, joined "Squawk Box" on Monday to discuss why he feels social media companies should be regulated, especially when it comes to user data.

data.title: Twitter has acquired its first design firm ever. Here's why
data.text: You might have never heard of Ueno, but it's the first design studio that Twitter has ever acquired. For years, Twitter has faced criticism for enabling harassment and the spread of misinformation and, in recent months, the company has shown signs of trying to right its course.

data.title: Tech crackdown on Trump isn't a free speech issue, says Joanne Lipman
data.text: YouTube, Google, Facebook, Twitter, Snapchat and other tech companies have banned or restricted President Donald Trump's accounts or other pro-Trump channels since last week's riots in Washington. Joanne Lipman, journalist and distinguished journalism fellow at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, and Dan Primack, business editor at Axios, joined "Squawk Box" on Monday to discuss.

data.title: Twitter shares drop in first trading day after Trump ban
data.text: Twitter made the decision to remove the president "due to the risk of further incitement of violence," after a deadly riot took place at the U.S. Capitol.

data.title: Twitter stock plunges after banning President Trump
data.text: Twitter's stock price tumbled early Monday as investors appeared to balk at the social network's decision to ban President Trump from posting. Shares in the San Francisco-based company tumbled 7.5 percent to $47.60 as of 8:07 a.m.

data.title: After years of hesitance, Corporate America is taking action against President Trump
data.text: Corporate America has long had a complex relationship with President Donald Trump. Many executives have been critical of his unpredictability, restrictions on immigration and ready use of tariffs — all while benefiting from his 2017 tax cuts and deregulation agenda.

data.title: Twitter Shares Down 7% In Pre-Market Trading After Trump Is Permanently Banned From The Platform
data.text: Twitter banned the president “due to the risk of further incitement of violence” after Trump incited violence among his supporters who went on to storm the Capitol Wednesday.

data.title: Twitter Shares Under Pressure After Ban on Trump's Account
data.text: Twitter's shares are down on Monday, as investors assess the effects of a ban on President Donald Trump.

data.title: Big tech cracks down on President Trump's online presence
data.text: Big tech companies like c and Twitter are banning President Trump from using their platforms. Sara Fischer, Media Reporter at Axios, joins Worldwide Exchange to discuss what this means for the companies' reputations and for regulatory implications.

data.title: Twitter stock tumbles 10% after Trump is permanently banned from the platform
data.text: Twitter stock fell as much as 10% in premarket trading on Monday after the social-media company permanently banned President Trump's account on Friday evening. Twitter's bosses suspended Trump's account — which had about 88 million followers — after the world leader's fanning of conspiracies about voter fraud and election theft spurred thousands of his supporters to lay siege to the Capitol last week.

data.title: Shares of Twitter drop following permanent ban on Trump's account
data.text: Shares of Twitter fell 6% on Monday, following an announcement by the microblogger late last week that it has permanently suspended the account of President Donald Trump. "After close review of recent Tweets from the @realDonaldTrump account and the context around them - specifically how they are being received and interpreted on and off Twitter - we have permanently suspended the account due to the risk of further incitement of violence," Twitter said in a blog post Friday.
